The Stirling cycle consists of four processes: 1. A → B: Isothermal expansion (constant temperature). 2. B → C: Isochoric (constant volume) cooling. 3. C → D: Isothermal compression (constant temperature). 4. D → A: Isochoric (constant volume) heating.
The transition from state B to state C is an isochoric process, meaning the volume remains constant while the pressure decreases.

The thermal motion of gas molecules is directly related to the temperature of the gas. Higher temperature corresponds to more intense thermal motion, while lower temperature corresponds to less intense thermal motion.

For an ideal gas, temperature T is proportional to the product of pressure P and volume V (from the ideal gas law: PV = nRT). Since the volume is constant during the B → C transition, the temperature is directly proportional to the pressure.
In the P-V diagram, during the B → C transition, the volume remains constant (vertical line), but the pressure decreases.
